content:
I'm trying, with difficulty, to define what the tuple type is. I think part of my problem is how do we define what a type actually is? This is stopping me from actually submitting a PR with a bunch of updates on tuples for the reference. So, what are y'alls thoughts on the following definition?

The tuple type is a structural type for heterogeneous lists of other types. Each entry in the list is an element of the tuple. The position of the element makes it the nth element using zero (0) as the initial index.
Actually, I like this definition. I'm going to go with it.
@isHavvy seems ok, maybe a bit "jargon-heavy". I guess I might have leaned on something like "anonymous struct", but maybe that's confusing given that the fields are numbered.
The reference ends up being jargon heavy in general. There's a lot of terms to be defined. And this paragraph is focused on defining the jargon.
if you like jargon, it might be worth bringing up "product type" (that's the type theory name for this)
Hmm, perhaps. Though if I do that, I'd want to do that to all of the sum and product types at the same time.
I think (technical, precise) jargon can be useful, but it has to be used carefully ;)
